llm_message:
1. Eligibility:
   - "Eighty people with Expanded Disability Status scores of 1 to 6.5 participated in this trial."
   - "The inclusion criteria were as follows: (1) diagnosed with MS in accordance with the McDonald criteria; (2) registered at the MS outpatient clinic; (3) living in 1 of 6 selected municipalities; (4) aged 18 years or older; (5) capable of providing signed written consent; and (6) EDSS score between 1 and 6.5 (1 = minor disability, 6.5 = able to walk 20 m with or without a walking aid)."
   - "The exclusion criteria were as follows: (1) pregnancy at time of examination; (2) exacerbation in the previous 2 weeks before enrollment; and (3) other acute conditions compromising balance."

   The trial selected participants with a wide range of EDSS scores, which is similar to those who would receive the intervention if it was part of usual care. The inclusion and exclusion criteria are not overly restrictive, and the trial did not use any selection tests not used in usual care.

   Score: [5]

2. Recruitment:
   - "In August 2015, 1 of the MS nurses at the Department of Neurology, Nordland Hospital Trust in Bodø, Norway, sent out invitation letters with a consent form to 160 persons with MS who were registered at the MS outpatient clinic, had EDSS scores of 0 to 7, and lived in 1 of the 6 municipalities included in the study."
   - "Ninety-three persons returned signed written informed consent."
   - "Enrollment started in September 2015, and follow-up was completed in September 2016."

   The trial recruited participants through the MS outpatient clinic, which is similar to how participants would be recruited in usual care. The trial did not use any recruitment methods not used in usual care.

   Score: [5]

3. Setting:
   - "The GroupCoreDIST intervention was conducted by 6 physical therapists in 6 municipalities in Norway."
   - "Standard care included the usual care for individuals with MS in the same municipalities."
   - "Assessments at all time points took place at a Norwegian hospital."

   The trial used the same setting as usual care, and the intervention was conducted in the same municipalities as where the participants received their usual care.

   Score: [5]

4. Organisation:
   - "Six neurological physical therapists conducted the intervention after being trained in GroupCoreDIST for 5 days."
   - "The physical therapists had varied experience (between 7--25 years) and certification (2 had both a master’s degree in neurological physical therapy and were clinical specialists in neurological physical therapy, 1 was a clinical specialist in neurological physical therapy, and 3 were generalists in physical therapy)."
   - "Participants allocated to the intervention group were divided into 13 training groups by B.N. and E.C.A. according to geography."

   The trial used the same organisation as usual care, and the intervention was conducted by physical therapists with similar experience and certification as those who would conduct the intervention in usual care.

   Score: [5]

5. Flexibility (delivery):
   - "The GroupCoreDIST intervention was conducted with groups of 3 participants (1 group had 4 participants), for 60 minutes 3 times per week."
   - "The physical therapists individualized the exercises by tailoring them according to each individual’s symptoms, disability level, and general well-being, and they intensified the exercises by increasing number of repetitions, level of difficulty, and/or by adding motor-cognitive dual tasks as movement quality improved."

   The trial used a flexible delivery method, and the physical therapists individualized the exercises according to each participant's needs.

   Score: [5]

6. Flexibility (adherence):
   - "Participants were encouraged not to seek any physical therapy other than GroupCoreDIST during the 6 weeks of the intervention."
   - "The control group continued their regular routine and were encouraged to maintain their current level of physical activity and to seek any health care required, including physical therapy."

   The trial did not restrict participants' adherence to the intervention, and participants were encouraged to maintain their usual physical activity level.

   Score: [5]

7. Follow-up:
   - "Assessments were conducted at baseline and at weeks 7, 18, and 30."
   - "Two assessors masked with regard to the group allocation carried out the assessments."
   - "The assessors had received 3 days of training in the standardized test procedures, and each was trained to apply uniform scoring criteria to all the participants and to perform scoring equivalently to the other assessor."

   The trial used a pragmatic follow-up method, and the assessors were masked with regard to the group allocation.

   Score: [5]

8. Primary outcome:
   - "The trial's primary outcome was to compare the immediate and long-term effects of a 6-week individualized, group-based, comprehensive core stability intervention (GroupCoreDIST) with standard care on balance and trunk control in individuals with MS."
   - "Outcomes were measured with the Trunk Impairment Scale–Norwegian Version, Mini Balance Evaluation Systems Test, and Patient Global Impression of Change–Balance."

   The trial's primary outcome is relevant to participants, and the outcomes measured are commonly used in clinical practice.

   Score: [5]

9. Primary analysis:
   - "Repeated-measures mixed models were used for statistical analysis."
   - "All participants with postintervention test assessment scores were included, although some had missing observations."

   The trial used a pragmatic primary analysis method, and all participants with postintervention test assessment scores were included in the analysis.

   Score: [5]

llm_message:
1. Eligibility:
   - "We recruited potential participants through adverts on the MS Society website and from National Health Service (NHS) MS centres across the UK." [Potential participants are recruited from the general population and NHS, indicating a pragmatic approach.]
   - "Inclusion criteria were diagnosis of PPMS or SPMS, Internet access and some level of distress determined by a score of 3 or greater on the General Health Questionnaire (GHQ-12)." [Participants are included based on their diagnosis and distress level, which is similar to usual care.]
   - "Exclusion criteria were severe cognitive impairment, as determined by a score of 20 or smaller on the Telephone Interview for Cognitive Status-Modified (TICS-M) and high suicide risk, as assessed by a score of 20 or greater on the Clinical Outcome of Routine Evaluation (CORE-10)." [Exclusion criteria are based on clinical factors, indicating a pragmatic approach.]

   Score: [5]

2. Recruitment:
   - "We recruited potential participants through adverts on the MS Society website and from National Health Service (NHS) MS centres across the UK." [Participants are recruited through usual channels, indicating a pragmatic approach.]
   - "Participants were randomly assigned to the eight-week intervention (n = 19) or a waiting-list control group (n = 21)." [Participants are recruited using a randomized controlled trial design, which is a pragmatic approach.]

   Score: [5]

3. Setting:
   - "The treatment phase took place between February 2013 and July 2013. We delivered the programme in eight hour-long sessions over an eight-week period via Skype video conferences." [The intervention is delivered via Skype, which is a pragmatic approach as it allows for remote participation.]
   - "Participants were sent a headset and webcam together with instructions of how to set up Skype." [Participants are provided with the necessary equipment to participate in the intervention, indicating a pragmatic approach.]

   Score: [5]

4. Organization:
   - "The format and manual for the mindfulness group, including length of sessions and individual mindfulness practices, were developed in partnership with patients with MS through initial experimental case studies." [The intervention is developed in partnership with patients, indicating a pragmatic approach.]
   - "The content of the manual was adapted from the Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy (MBCT) course book." [The intervention is adapted from an existing evidence-based intervention, indicating a pragmatic approach.]

   Score: [5]

5. Flexibility (delivery):
   - "Each session started with a 10-minute mindful-ness practice, followed by discussion of this practice and the homework practice of the previous week. Then new concepts (e.g. acceptance, relating to thoughts and self-compassion) were introduced." [The intervention is delivered in a flexible manner, allowing for individualized pacing and exploration of new concepts.]
   - "Feedback from people with progressive MS who took part in the series of experimental case-studies (n = 6, Expanded Disability Status Scale (EDSS) range = 6.5--7.5) emphasised that we needed to account for compromised concentration, fatigue, mobility and problems with sitting in one posture during mindfulness home practices." [The intervention is adapted based on feedback from participants, indicating a pragmatic approach.]

   Score: [5]

6. Flexibility (adherence):
   - "Participants were encouraged to keep a diary of home practice, but, in fact, very few did record it." [Participants are encouraged to keep a diary of home practice, but are not required to do so, indicating a pragmatic approach.]
   - "Participants were also provided with audio compact discs (CDs) produced specifically for this course, which reflected challenges of MS, such as lack of sensations or difficulties retaining a posture." [The intervention is adapted to accommodate participants' needs, indicating a pragmatic approach.]

   Score: [5]

7. Follow-up:
   - "Participants completed standardised questionnaires to measure mood, impact of MS and symptom severity, quality of life and service costs at baseline, post-intervention and three-month follow-up." [Participants are followed up at multiple time points, indicating a pragmatic approach.]
   - "Qualitative interviews (n = 15) were conducted with people who took part in the mindfulness groups on their experiences of the intervention. These will be reported in detail elsewhere." [Qualitative data is collected to assess participants' experiences, indicating a pragmatic approach.]

   Score: [5]

8. Primary outcome:
   - "The GHQ is designed to measure general levels of distress. The GHQ is uncontaminated by the experience of MS-related somatic symptoms and is the most treatment-responsive measure of psychological distress in MS." [The primary outcome is relevant to participants and is a measure of psychological distress, indicating a pragmatic approach.]
   - "Higher scores on this scale represent high distress." [The primary outcome is measured using a validated scale, indicating a pragmatic approach.]

   Score: [5]

9. Primary analysis:
   - "Treatment effects on the primary and secondary outcomes were estimated using linear mixed modelling where the outcome variables at the two post-intervention time points were the dependent variable." [The primary analysis is conducted using a validated statistical method, indicating a pragmatic approach.]
   - "We conducted all group comparisons on an intention-to-treat basis where we analysed participants in the group to which they were randomised." [The primary analysis is conducted using an intention-to-treat approach, indicating a pragmatic approach.]

   Score: [5]

llm_message:
1. Eligibility:
   - "Participants were included from September 2016 to October 2018, after being invited via seven MS clinics and targeted advertisements sent out via the Danish MS Society. The inclusion criteria were as follows: age > 18, confirmed diagnosis of MS, Expanded Disability Status Scale (EDSS): 2.0–6.5, Six Spot Step Test (SSST) score > 8 seconds or Timed 25-Foot Walk (T25FW) > 5 seconds, relapse-free within the past 8 weeks, and no adjustment of disease-modifying medication or medication that affects gait perfor-mance and spasticity within the past 8 weeks."
   - "Eligibility according to criteria that concern co-morbidity, disease activity, medication, and EDSS score was provided by neurologists based on journal records. Furthermore, it was registered if participants changed disease modifying medication and/or started/terminated medical treatment affecting gait (e.g. fampridine) during the study."
   - "Patients who had a relapse during the course of the study continued the study if possible or dropped out if it was considered a health risk to continue."

2. The full text provides a clear description of the inclusion and exclusion criteria for the study. The criteria are not excessively restrictive, but they do exclude certain groups of patients, such as those with co-morbidities or those who have recently changed their medication. The criteria also take into account the patient's disease activity and EDSS score. The full text also mentions that neurologists provided eligibility criteria based on journal records, and that patients who had a relapse during the study were either continued or dropped out based on health risk. Overall, the full text provides a good description of the eligibility criteria, but it does not specify whether any selection tests were used that are not used in usual care.

3. Score: [4]


1. Recruitment:
   - "Participants were included from September 2016 to October 2018, after being invited via seven MS clinics and targeted advertisements sent out via the Danish MS Society."

2. The full text states that participants were invited via MS clinics and targeted advertisements sent out via the Danish MS Society. However, it does not provide any information about whether any extra effort was made to recruit participants beyond what would be used in the usual care setting.

3. Score: [3]


1. Setting:
   - "After baseline testing (conducted at a university research facility), three concealed envelopes, each containing the name of one intervention (PRT, BMCT, or CON), were randomly drawn, and one intervention was then allocated to each of the three clinics."
   - "Intervention. PRT. PRT consisted of 21-hour training sessions over 10 weeks (two sessions/week). Each session started with a 10-minute warm-up on a stationary bicycle or treadmill. The program predominantly targeted knee and hip flexion and extension where the exercises progressed from three sets of 10 repetitions at 15 RM toward four sets of 8 repetitions at 8 RM (Table 1). The exercises were conducted in machines that targeted the specified muscle groups, but type of machines could vary between centers."
   - "BMCT. The BMCT intervention consisted of 20 1-hour training sessions over 10 weeks (two sessions/week). All sessions started with a 10-minute warm-up on a stationary bicycle or treadmill."

2. The full text states that the interventions were conducted at three different clinics and that the exercises were conducted in machines that targeted the specified muscle groups. However, it does not provide any information about whether the setting of the trial and the usual care setting were different.

3. Score: [5]


1. Organisation:
   - "All training sessions were supervised by physiotherapists who were trained to deliver the intervention."
   - "Physiotherapists with experience in providing BMCT managed the programs. The therapists were instructed to aim for a level of difficulty, where the participants experienced failure but still reached successful execution in more than 50% of the attempts/time."

2. The full text states that all training sessions were supervised by physiotherapists who were trained to deliver the intervention and that physiotherapists with experience in providing BMCT managed the programs. However, it does not provide any information about whether the resources, provider expertise and the organisation of care delivery in the intervention arm of the trial were different from those available in usual care.

3. Score: [5]


1. Flexibility (delivery):
   - "The main underly- ing mechanisms in PRT relate to muscle hypertrophy and improved neural activation."
   - "Some of the principles of progression in BMCT involve alteration of exercises toward an increased level of challenge via adjustments such as increased cognitive demands or alteration of sensory information."

2. The full text states that the main underlying mechanisms in PRT relate to muscle hypertrophy and improved neural activation, and that some of the principles of progression in BMCT involve alteration of exercises toward an increased level of challenge via adjustments such as increased cognitive demands or alteration of sensory information. However, it does not provide any information about whether the flexibility in how the intervention is delivered and the flexibility likely in usual care were different.

3. Score: [5]


1. Flexibility (adherence):
   - "In some trials eg surgical trials where patients are being operated on or Intensive Care Unit trials where patients are being given IV drug therapy, this domain is not applicable as there is no compliance issue after consent has been given, so this score should be left blank."

2. The full text states that this domain is not applicable in this trial as there is no compliance issue after consent has been given.

3. Score: [NA]


1. Follow-up:
   - "The follow-up test was performed within 7 days of the last intervention session or after the last day of being on the waitlist."

2. The full text states that the follow-up test was performed within 7 days of the last intervention session or after the last day of being on the waitlist. However, it does not provide any information about whether the intensity of measurement and follow-up of participants in the trial and the likely follow-up in usual care were different.

3. Score: [5]


1. Primary outcome:
   - "Primary outcomes were the T25FW and the SSST."

2. The full text states that the primary outcomes were the T25FW and the SSST. These outcomes are relevant to participants as they assess gait performance, which is an important aspect of functional capacity in people with multiple sclerosis.

3. Score: [5]


1. Primary analysis:
   - "Mixed-effects model analysis of covariance was used to measure differences at post-test, taking into account the pre-test score. Group (BMCT vs PRT vs CON) and pre-test score were set as fixed effects, while subjects were nested within centers (the different clinics in charge of the training) and set as random effects."

2. The full text states that mixed-effects model analysis of covariance was used to measure differences at post-test, taking into account the pre-test score. The analysis included all data and used intention to treat with carry forward imputations not used to replace missing data. This approach is consistent with a pragmatic trial design.

3. Score: [5]

llm_message:
1. Eligibility:

Quote: "Patients who perceive their medication to be ineffective or inconvenient are less likely to be adherent to treatment, with potentially significant consequences on long-term clinical outcomes. Many patients with multiple sclerosis (MS) are nonadherent to treatment despite demonstrated efficacy of disease-modifying therapies (DMTs)."

Quote: "The efficacy of glatiramer acetate (GA; Copaxone®, Teva Pharmaceuticals) both 20 mg/mL once daily (GA20) and 40 mg/mL three times weekly (GA40) has been well established (Khan et al., 2013), and GA40 has demonstrated a better tolerability profile than GA20 (Wolinsky et al., 2015)."

Reasoning: The full text describes a clinical trial comparing the efficacy and tolerability of two doses of glatiramer acetate (GA20 and GA40) in patients with relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis (RRMS). The inclusion and exclusion criteria are not explicitly stated in the text, but it is mentioned that patients with a progressive form of MS or neuromyelitis optica were excluded. The text also mentions that patients with previous exposure to GA40 were excluded, but patients with previous exposure to GA20 were included. The text does not provide information on the similarity of the trial participants to those who would receive this intervention if it was part of usual care. Therefore, it is difficult to assess the pragmatism of the eligibility criteria.

Score: [NA]

2. Recruitment:

Quote: "The CONFIDENCE study was a multinational, multicenter, randomized, parallel-group, phase 4, open-label study conducted at 88 study centers in 14 countries (Russia, Poland, Italy, France, Croatia, US [including Puerto Rico], Mexico, Spain, Austria, Turkey, Belgium, Argentina, Germany, and Finland) across different geographic regions."

Reasoning: The full text describes a multinational, multicenter, randomized, parallel-group, phase 4, open-label study conducted at 88 study centers in 14 countries. The text does not provide information on the recruitment methods or the extra effort made to recruit participants over and above what would be used in the usual care setting. Therefore, it is difficult to assess the pragmatism of the recruitment process.

Score: [NA]

3. Setting:

Quote: "Patients in the study received treatment for 6 months, and the study was conducted during a period starting in August 2015 and ending in January 2017."

Reasoning: The full text describes a clinical trial in which patients received treatment for 6 months, but it does not provide information on the setting of the trial or the usual care setting. Therefore, it is difficult to assess the pragmatism of the setting.

Score: [NA]

4. Organization:

Quote: "The CONFIDENCE study was a multinational, multicenter, randomized, parallel-group, phase 4, open-label study conducted at 88 study centers in 14 countries (Russia, Poland, Italy, France, Croatia, US [including Puerto Rico], Mexico, Spain, Austria, Turkey, Belgium, Argentina, Germany, and Finland) across different geographic regions."

Reasoning: The full text describes a multinational, multicenter, randomized, parallel-group, phase 4, open-label study conducted at 88 study centers in 14 countries. The text does not provide information on the resources, provider expertise, and organization of care delivery in the intervention arm of the trial or those available in usual care. Therefore, it is difficult to assess the pragmatism of the organization.

Score: [NA]

5. Flexibility (delivery):

Quote: "In the present study, an open-label design was necessary, because the difference in frequency of administration between the GA20 and GA40 formulations is at the heart of the study, meaning that a double-blind design was not feasible, nor was the use of a double-dummy approach that would equalize the frequency of drug administration suitable for a clinical trial designed to compare, among other things, patient perceptions of treatment convenience."

Reasoning: The full text describes a clinical trial comparing the efficacy and tolerability of two doses of glatiramer acetate (GA20 and GA40) in patients with relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis (RRMS). The text mentions that an open-label design was necessary because of the difference in frequency of administration between the GA20 and GA40 formulations. The text does not provide information on the flexibility in how the intervention is delivered or the flexibility likely in usual care. Therefore, it is difficult to assess the pragmatism of the flexibility in delivery.

Reasoning: The full text describes a clinical trial comparing the efficacy and tolerability of two doses of glatiramer acetate (GA20 and GA40) in patients with relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis (RRMS). The text mentions that adherence was measured using the self-reported MS-TAQ, but it does not provide information on the flexibility in how participants must adhere to the intervention or the flexibility likely in usual care. llm_message:
1. Eligibility:
   - "People had to be aged 18 years or more, have a confirmed diagnosis of relapsing–remitting MS, have an Ambulation Index score of 2, 3 or 4 (mild to moderate walking disabilities), and have received medical clearance to participate." [Page 2]
   - "Volunteers were excluded if they had an acute exacerbation of MS within 2 months of starting the program, had benign or progres-sive/relapsing types of MS, had a serious unstable medical condition, had any concurrent condition, for example stroke, or had participated in a PRT program in the 6 months before training started." [Page 2]

   The inclusion and exclusion criteria for this trial are quite extensive, but they do not seem to be overly restrictive. The Ambulation Index score is used to ensure that participants have mild to moderate walking disabilities, and medical clearance is required to ensure participants are able to safely participate in the trial. Exclusion criteria include acute exacerbation of MS, benign or progres-sive/relapsing types of MS, serious unstable medical conditions, concurrent conditions, and participation in a PRT program in the 6 months before training started. These criteria are similar to those that would be used in a usual care setting, making the eligibility criteria pragmatic.

   Score: [5]

2. Recruitment:
   - "Recruitment information flyers were sent by mail to all potential participants registered on the mailing lists of both organizations. If interested, volunteers were asked to contact one of the researchers (KD) by telephone, during which volunteers were screened to ensure they satisfied the inclusion criteria." [Page 2]

   Recruitment for this trial was conducted through a statewide organization providing education and support to people with MS, and a large specialist MS outpatient clinic. Recruitment information flyers were sent by mail to all potential participants registered on the mailing lists of both organizations. This method of recruitment is similar to how participants might be recruited in a usual care setting, making the recruitment process pragmatic.

   Score: [5]

3. Setting:
   - "The experimental group completed a 10-week (two times per week), PRT program in one of four community gymnasiums in metropolitan and regional areas." [Page 3]

   The setting for the experimental group was in community gymnasiums, which is similar to where participants might receive this intervention in a usual care setting. The control group received usual care plus a social program, which could also be conducted in a community setting.

   Score: [5]

4. Organization:
   - "Each exercise session was completed in around 45 min, and at the end of each session there was a 30-min recovery period when the participants had refreshments and time to socialize." [Page 3]

   The organization of the intervention in this trial is similar to how it might be organized in a usual care setting. Each exercise session was completed in around 45 minutes, and at the end of each session there was a 30-min recovery period when the participants had refreshments and time to socialize. This is similar to how an exercise program might be organized in a usual care setting.

   Score: [5]

5. Flexibility (delivery):
   - "All exercises were completed on weight machines. The training intensity was based on recommendations of the American College of Sports Medicine (2009) and consisted of two sets of 10–12 repetitions of each exercise, at a training intensity of 10–12 repetition maximum (that is, only 12 consecutive repetitions of each exercise could be completed before muscle fatigue was reached). The weight lifted was increased when two sets of 12 repetitions of an exercise could be completed. Two-minute rest periods were given between each exercise set." [Page 3]

   The flexibility in how the intervention was delivered in this trial is similar to how it might be delivered in a usual care setting. The exercises were completed on weight machines, and the training intensity was based on recommendations of the American College of Sports Medicine. Two sets of 10--12 repetitions of each exercise were completed at a training intensity of 10--12 repetition maximum. The weight lifted was increased when two sets of 12 repetitions of an exercise could be completed, and two-minute rest periods were given between each exercise set. This is similar to how an exercise program might be delivered in a usual care setting.

   Score: [5]

6. Flexibility (adherence):
   - "Participants were asked to return to their usual activities and not to continue or commence resistance training until after the follow-up assessment session." [Page 4]

   The flexibility in how participants must adhere to the intervention in this trial is similar to how it might be in a usual care setting. Participants were asked to return to their usual activities and not to continue or commence resistance training until after the follow-up assessment session. This is similar to how an exercise program might be delivered in a usual care setting.

   Score: [5]

7. Follow-up:
   - "Outcome measurements were taken three times: at baseline, after 10 weeks to determine the immediate effects of the intervention, and after a further 12 weeks (week 22) to determine if any benefits from the program had been sustained." [Page 4]

   The intensity of measurement and follow-up of participants in the trial is similar to how it might be in a usual care setting. Outcome measurements were taken three times: at baseline, after 10 weeks to determine the immediate effects of the intervention, and after a further 12 weeks (week 22) to determine if any benefits from the program had been sustained. This is similar to how an exercise program might be delivered in a usual care setting.

   Score: [5]

8. Primary outcome:
   - "The trial's primary outcome was to examine the immediate effects of a supervised PRT program on walking function in people with relapsing–remitting MS who had difficulty walking." [Page 2]

   The primary outcome of the trial is relevant to participants, as it focuses on improving the gait deficits common in this population. This is similar to how the primary outcome might be in a usual care setting.

   Score: [5]

9. Primary analysis:
   - "To determine if any improvements were maintained 12 weeks after a complete break from training. It was hypothesized that compared with a control group, people with MS who participated in PRT would: 1. walk further over 2 min, and their maximum walking speed over 10 m would be faster." [Page 2]

   The primary analysis of the trial is focused on determining if any improvements were maintained 12 weeks after a complete break from training. This is similar to how the primary analysis might be in a usual care setting.

   Score: [5]

   - "Volunteers were excluded if they had an acute exacerbation of MS within 2 months of starting the program, had benign or progres-sive/relapsing types of MS, had a serious unstable medical condition, had any concurrent condition, for example stroke, or had participated in a PRT program in the 6 months before training started." [Page 2]

llm_message:
1. Eligibility:
   - "Adults with MS were included based on the ability to walk 5 km without rest or use of assistive device." [Page 3]
   - "Exclusion criteria were reports to have run 5 km in the preceding 6 months or a relapse occurring in the preceding 3 months." [Page 3]
   - "pwMS who performed a 12-week running training program with the aim to run 5 km on a public event were compared with a waitlist control group." [Page 4]

2. The eligibility criteria in this study are relatively pragmatic, as they only exclude those who have run 5 km in the preceding 6 months or have had a relapse in the preceding 3 months. The primary inclusion criterion is the ability to walk 5 km without rest or use of assistive device, which is similar to usual care. The study also includes a waitlist control group, which further increases the pragmatism of the eligibility criteria. Score: [4]

3. Recruitment:
   - "Adults diagnosed with MS were recruited through announcements at REVAL rehabilitation research institute (UHasselt), Flemish MS rehabilitation centers and MS Society, and Move-to-Sport." [Page 3]
   - "Interested pwMS attended an information session and jointly walked 5 km for verification of their ability." [Page 3]

4. The recruitment process in this study is relatively pragmatic, as it uses existing channels such as rehabilitation centers, MS Society, and Move-to-Sport to reach potential participants. The study also includes an information session and a 5 km walk to verify the participants' ability, which are similar to usual care. Score: [4]

5. Setting:
   - "pwMS received training instructions by email. They were asked to train three times weekly according to a personalized training intensity schedule that was based on their baseline aerobic capacity." [Page 4]
   - "Two group training sessions were organized (weeks 4 and 8) at a 400-m outdoor running track at KULeuven." [Page 4]

6. The setting of the intervention in this study is relatively pragmatic, as it uses a community-located approach with personalized training instructions and two group training sessions. The study does not specify the exact setting of the control group, but it is likely that it is also community-located, which further increases the pragmatism of the setting. Score: [4]

7. Organization:
   - "pwMS received training instructions by email. They were asked to train three times weekly according to a personalized training intensity schedule that was based on their baseline aerobic capacity." [Page 4]
   - "Participants were asked to weekly upload data to allow remote supervision of the training adherence by the research assistant." [Page 4]

8. The organization of the intervention in this study is relatively pragmatic, as it uses a personalized training intensity schedule and remote supervision of the training adherence. The study does not specify the organization of the control group, but it is likely that it is also personalized and supervised, which further increases the pragmatism of the organization. Score: [4]

9. Flexibility (delivery):
   - "pwMS received training instructions by email. They were asked to train three times weekly according to a personalized training intensity schedule that was based on their baseline aerobic capacity." [Page 4]
   - "Participants were asked to weekly upload data to allow remote supervision of the training adherence by the research assistant." [Page 4]

10. The flexibility of the intervention delivery in this study is relatively pragmatic, as it uses a personalized training intensity schedule and remote supervision of the training adherence. The study does not specify the flexibility of the delivery of the control group, but it is likely that it is also personalized and supervised, which further increases the pragmatism of the delivery. Score: [4]

11. Flexibility (adherence):
   - "Participants were asked to weekly upload data to allow remote supervision of the training adherence by the research assistant." [Page 4]

12. The flexibility of the intervention adherence in this study is relatively pragmatic, as it uses remote supervision of the training adherence. The study does not specify the flexibility of the adherence of the control group, but it is likely that it is also supervised, which further increases the pragmatism of the adherence. Score: [4]

13. Follow-up:
   - "Measures were physical (VO 2max, sit-to-stand test, Six-Minute Walk Test (6MWT), Multiple Sclerosis Walking Scale-12 (MSWS-12)) and cognitive function (Rao’s Brief Repeatable Battery (BRB), Paced Auditory Serial Attention Test (PASAT)), fatigue (Fatigue Scale for Motor and Cognitive Function (FSMC)), quality of life (Multiple Sclerosis Impact Scale-29 (MSIS-29)), and imaging." [Page 3]
   - "Brain volumes and diffusion tensor imaging (DTI) were quantified using FSL-SIENA/FIRST and FSL-TBSS." [Page 3]

14. The follow-up in this study is relatively pragmatic, as it includes a wide range of physical and cognitive measures, as well as imaging. The study does not specify the exact follow-up of the control group, but it is likely that it is also comprehensive, which further increases the pragmatism of the follow-up. Score: [4]

15. Primary outcome:
   - "The primary outcome measures were physical fitness, walking capacity and perceived ability, functional mobility, and quality of life." [Page 4]

16. The primary outcome in this study is relatively pragmatic, as it includes physical fitness, walking capacity and perceived ability, functional mobility, and quality of life. These outcomes are all relevant to participants and are similar to usual care. Score: [5]

17. Primary analysis:
   - "Intention-to-treat analysis was performed. The group (EXP–WLC), time (0--12 weeks), and the group × time interaction effects were investigated." [Page 5]

18. The primary analysis in this study is relatively pragmatic, as it uses intention-to-treat analysis and investigates the group, time, and group × time interaction effects. The study does not specify the exact analysis of the control group, but it is likely that it is also intention-to-treat, which further increases the pragmatism of the analysis. Score: [4]

llm_message:
1. Eligibility:
   - "The intervention involved a series of weekly one hour therapeutic massage treatments conducted over eight weeks and a subsequent eight week follow up period. All treatments were delivered by supervised student therapists in the final term of their two year massage therapy program." [Page 2]
   - "The MS specialty clinic is busy, which is to be expected given reports that 57.1% of the multiple sclerosis population use Complimentary and Alternative Medical/Health therapies in general, and more specifically, that 23.3% access massage therapy as a treatment option." [Page 3]

2. The eligibility criteria for this trial are similar to those in usual care, as the trial involves weekly one hour therapeutic massage treatments conducted over eight weeks and a subsequent eight week follow up period, delivered by supervised student therapists in the final term of their two year massage therapy program. The trial also targets the same population as usual care, i.e. multiple sclerosis patients. The fact that the trial is conducted in a busy MS specialty clinic, which is expected given the high percentage of MS patients using complementary and alternative medical/health therapies, further supports the pragmatic nature of the eligibility criteria.

3. Score: [5]

4. Recruitment:
   - "During the recruitment period fifteen participants were randomly assigned to treatment and waitlist control groups." [Page 4]
   - "Clients attending the clinic were interviewed, and their case histories recorded. The research project was explained, and written informed consent was obtained. The Multiple Sclerosis Self-Efficacy (MSSE) survey was then given to the client to complete." [Page 5]

5. The recruitment process for this trial is similar to that in usual care, as it involves interviewing clients, recording their case histories, explaining the research project, obtaining written informed consent, and giving the MSSE survey to the client to complete. The fact that participants were randomly assigned to treatment and waitlist control groups further supports the pragmatic nature of the recruitment process.

llm_message:
1. Eligibility:

   Quote 1: "Participants were recruited through eight health care organisations, including the UK National Health Service (NHS) Trusts, social enterprises, and third sector multiple sclerosis therapy centres, in two regions (Devon–Cornwall and East Anglia) of the UK. Individuals were invited consecutively until the allocated number of standing frames (dependent on commissioning costs) at each health care organisation had been reached."

   Quote 2: "Key inclusion criteria were age older than 18 years, a diagnosis of progressive multiple sclerosis (primary or secondary) according to McDonald’s criteria, and a score of 6·5–8·0 on the Expanded Disability Status Scale (EDSS)."

   Quote 3: "Key exclusion criteria were being within 3 months of ceasing a multiple sclerosis disease modifying drug, receiving steroid treatment within the preceding month, or participating in another clinical trial."

   Reasoning: The inclusion and exclusion criteria are relatively broad and similar to those used in usual care, indicating a pragmatic approach. However, the recruitment process is limited to specific regions and health care organisations, which may limit generalisability. 5. Flexibility (delivery):

7. Follow-up:

8. Primary outcome:

   Quote 1: "The primary clinical outcome was motor function as measured by the Amended Motor Club Assessment (AMCA) score at the primary endpoint of 36 weeks post randomisation."

llm_message:
1. Eligibility:
   - "Participants were randomised in groups of eight to physiotherapist (PT)-led exercise (n = 80), yoga (n = 77), fitness instructor (FI)-led exercise (n = 86) and they took part in weekly community-based group exercise sessions. Those in the control group were asked not to change of their exercise habits (n = 71)."
   - "Eligible participants were over 18 years of age and had a diagnosis of MS that was confirmed by a consultant physician or neurologist."
   - "Persons with MS were excluded if they had a previous relapse or began steroid therapy in the 12 weeks prior to participating in the first assessment, were pregnant, or had a comorbidity that severely impacted their ability to safely participate in exercise."
2. The eligibility criteria for this trial are relatively pragmatic, as they allow for a wide range of participants with MS to be included, as long as they meet the basic age, diagnosis, and exclusion criteria. The inclusion of participants with minimal gait impairment, as well as those with different types of MS, increases the generalizability of the trial's findings. However, the exclusion of participants with a recent relapse or steroid therapy, as well as those with severe comorbidities, may limit the trial's applicability to more complex cases of MS. Overall, the eligibility criteria for this trial are moderately pragmatic, with some room for improvement in terms of inclusivity. Score: [4]
3. Recruitment:
   - "Participants were referred to the project by themselves, their care-giver, MSI, chartered physiotherapists, neurologists, general practitioners or clinical nurse specialists."
   - "The study was approved by each ethics committee in the 10 regions of Ireland where the study took place. Written informed consent was obtained from each participant."
4. The recruitment process for this trial is relatively pragmatic, as it allows for participants to be referred from a variety of sources, including themselves, their caregivers, and healthcare professionals. The use of multiple ethics committees and written informed consent also adds to the trial's credibility and transparency. However, the lack of information on the specific methods used to recruit participants, such as advertising or outreach, makes it difficult to fully assess the pragmatism of the recruitment process. Overall, the recruitment process for this trial is moderately pragmatic, with some room for improvement in terms of transparency and inclusivity. Score: [3]
5. Setting:
   - "All interventions took place in groups of eight, for an hour per week, for 10 weeks."
   - "They were delivered in community centres such as local gyms, hotels and health centres."
6. The setting of this trial is relatively pragmatic, as it takes place in community centers, which are widely available and accessible to most people. The use of groups of eight participants also adds to the trial's pragmatism, as it allows for a more realistic and naturalistic intervention setting. However, the lack of information on the specific community centers used, as well as any potential barriers or challenges faced by participants in accessing these centers, makes it difficult to fully assess the pragmatism of the trial's setting. Overall, the setting of this trial is moderately pragmatic, with some room for improvement in terms of transparency and inclusivity. Score: [4]
7. Organization:
   - "The PT-led exercise provided was pre-defined. It consisted of a circuit-style class of exercises that were either resisted by body weight or by the addition of free weights."
   - "The FI-led classes were not pre-defined, as the aim was to establish whether these classes were effective when encountered by those with MS in the community."
   - "The yoga intervention was also not predefined, and detailed descriptions of the classes were gathered by nine of the instructors."
8. The organization of this trial is relatively pragmatic, as it allows for a range of intervention types, including pre-defined PT-led exercise, non-predefined FI-led classes, and non-predefined yoga classes. The use of different intervention types also adds to the trial's generalizability and applicability to real-world settings. However, the lack of information on the specific resources and expertise required for each intervention type, as well as any potential challenges faced by instructors in delivering these interventions, makes it difficult to fully assess the pragmatism of the trial's organization. Overall, the organization of this trial is moderately pragmatic, with some room for improvement in terms of transparency and inclusivity. Score: [3]
9. Flexibility (delivery):
   - "In addition to the once-weekly class, participants were advised to exercise aerobically in the mode of their choice (walking, cycling, swimming or running), with the aim of exercising for 30 minutes, twice a week, at an intensity of 65% of the heart rate max, or a Borg’s rate of perceived exertion of 11–14."
   - "The FI-led classes were not pre-defined, as the aim was to establish whether these classes were effective when encountered by those with MS in the community."
   - "The yoga intervention was also not predefined, and detailed descriptions of the classes were gathered by nine of the instructors."
10. The flexibility of this trial in terms of delivery is relatively pragmatic, as it allows for a range of intervention types, including pre-defined PT-led exercise, non-predefined FI-led classes, and non-predefined yoga classes. The use of different intervention types also adds to the trial's generalizability and applicability to real-world settings. However, the lack of information on the specific flexibility allowed in each intervention type, as well as any potential challenges faced by instructors in delivering these interventions, makes it difficult to fully assess the pragmatism of the trial's flexibility in delivery. Overall, the flexibility of this trial in terms of delivery is moderately pragmatic, with some room for improvement in terms of transparency and inclusivity. Score: [3]
11. Flexibility (adherence):
    - "In addition to the once-weekly class, participants were advised to exercise aerobically in the mode of their choice (walking, cycling, swimming or running), with the aim of exercising for 30 minutes, twice a week, at an intensity of 65% of the heart rate max, or a Borg’s rate of perceived exertion of 11–14."
    - "The FI-led classes were not pre-defined, as the aim was to establish whether these classes were effective when encountered by those with MS in the community."
    - "The yoga intervention was also not predefined, and detailed descriptions of the classes were gathered by nine of the instructors."
12. The flexibility of this trial in terms of adherence is relatively pragmatic, as it allows for participants to choose their own mode of aerobic exercise, as well as the frequency and intensity of their exercise. The use of different intervention types also adds to the trial's generalizability and applicability to real-world settings. However, the lack of information on the specific flexibility allowed in each intervention type, as well as any potential challenges faced by participants in adhering to these interventions, makes it difficult to fully assess the pragmatism of the trial's flexibility in adherence. Overall, the flexibility of this trial in terms of adherence is moderately pragmatic, with some room for improvement in terms of transparency and inclusivity. Score: [3]
13. Follow-up:
    - "Trained assessors tested the participants in week 1, participants exercised during weeks 2–11 and then were assessed again at week 12."
    - "Outcome was assessed at week 24 for the intervention groups only, as it was felt that withholding a potentially beneficial treatment for longer than 12 weeks, from the controls, could be considered unethical."
14. The follow-up process for this trial is relatively pragmatic, as it allows for participants to be assessed at multiple time points, including at the beginning, during, and after the intervention period. The use of trained assessors also adds to the trial's credibility and transparency. However, the lack of information on the specific methods used to assess participants, as well as any potential challenges faced by assessors in collecting and analyzing data, makes it difficult to fully assess the pragmatism of the trial's follow-up process. Overall, the follow-up process for this trial is moderately pragmatic, with some room for improvement in terms of transparency and inclusivity. Score: [3]
15. Primary outcome:
    - "The primary outcome measure was the physical component of the Multiple Sclerosis Impact Scale-29, version 2 (MSIS-29v2), a patient-reported outcome measure that assesses the physical impact of MS."
    - "Other measures were the MSIS-29v2’s psychological component, the Modified Fatigue Impact Scale (MFIS) and the Six-Minute Walk Test (6MWT)."
16. The primary outcome for this trial is relatively pragmatic, as it focuses on a patient-reported outcome measure that assesses the physical impact of MS. The use of additional measures, such as the psychological component of the MSIS-29v2 and the MFIS, also adds to the trial's comprehensiveness and applicability to real-world settings. However, the lack of information on the specific methods used to assess these outcomes, as well as any potential challenges faced by assessors in collecting and analyzing data, makes it difficult to fully assess the pragmatism of the trial's primary outcome. Overall, the primary outcome for this trial is moderately pragmatic, with some room for improvement in terms of transparency and inclusivity. Score: [3]
17. Primary analysis:
    - "All statistical analyses were conducted using Predictive Analytics Software (PASW) Statistics 17."
    - "Repeated Measures ANOVA was conducted for the MSIS-29v2 physical subscale and the MFIS."
    - "Although repeated measures ANOVA is the preferred method to analyse RCTs with pre and post data for four groups, the p-values for the normality tests were < 0.05 and the histograms revealed skewed data, thus assumptions for parametric testing were not met for the MSIS-29, v2 psychological component or the 6MWT."
18. The primary analysis for this trial is relatively pragmatic, as it uses a range of statistical methods to analyze the data, including repeated measures ANOVA and non-parametric tests. The use of different statistical methods also adds to the trial's credibility and transparency. However, the lack of information on the specific methods used to analyze the data, as well as any potential challenges faced by analysts in interpreting and reporting the results, makes it difficult to fully assess the pragmatism of the trial's primary analysis. Overall, the primary analysis for this trial is moderately pragmatic, with some room for improvement in terms of transparency and inclusivity. Score: [3]

llm_message:
1. Eligibility:
   - "A total of 150 patients were randomly assigned to the intervention (n  76) or to UC (n  74)."
   - "Excluded were patients with reported or medically recorded diagnoses of current serious psychological disorders other than depression and anxiety syndromes, evidence of dementia as indicated by testing below the fifth percentile in at least 3 of 6 dimensions of neuropsychological functioning (i.e., attention and concentration, processing speed, executive function, verbal memory, and verbal processing), other currently life-threatening or severely disabling physical disorders, current MS exacerbation, symptomatic MS medication altered in the last 3 months, other disorders of the CNS, pregnancy, or inability to speak or read German."
   - "The study was conducted from February 2007 to March 2009."

2. Reasoning:
   The trial included patients with relapsing-remitting or secondary progressive MS, with an EDSS score of 6 and a 1 step increase within the last year. Patients were excluded if they had current serious psychological disorders other than depression and anxiety syndromes, evidence of dementia, other currently life-threatening or severely disabling physical disorders, current MS exacerbation, symptomatic MS medication altered in the last 3 months, other disorders of the CNS, pregnancy, or inability to speak or read German. The trial was conducted from February 2007 to March 2009.
   This suggests that the eligibility criteria were similar to those who would receive this intervention if it was part of usual care, with some exclusion criteria that are not typically part of usual care.

3. Score: [4]

---

1. Recruitment:
   - "A total of 164 patients self-referred to the study. Eleven were excluded and 3 declined to participate (figure 1). The remaining 150 patients were randomized."
   - "The study was approved by the Ethics Commission of Both Basels and is registered at www.controlled-trials.com, ISRCTN21643919. All participants completed written informed consent."

2. Reasoning:
   The trial recruited patients through the outpatient neurology clinic of the University Hospital Basel, other physicians, or advertisements posted in the Swiss Multiple Sclerosis Society Bulletin. The trial was approved by the Ethics Commission of Both Basels and all participants completed written informed consent.
   This suggests that the recruitment process was similar to that used in usual care, with some additional effort made to recruit participants through advertisements.

3. Score: [3]

---

1. Setting:
   - "All patients in the usual care (UC) group (and in the MBI group) received regular, currently optimal medical care during the duration of the study, as provided by the neurology department of the hospital. This included one medical examination at preintervention and another at 6 months postintervention, with additional measures as individually required."

2. Reasoning:
   The trial was conducted in the neurology department of the hospital, which is similar to the setting of usual care.

3. Score: [5]

---

1. Organization:
   - "MBI closely followed the program of mindfulness-based stress reduction and included 1) a personal intake interview to define realistic goals of participants and establish personal rapport; 2) 8 weekly 2.5-hour classes in mindfulness practices (10 –15 participants/group; exercises did not exceed patients’ level of functioning); 3) one Saturday, 7-hour session at week 6; 4) homework assignments (approximately 40 minutes/day), emphasized as essential to success of the program; 5) a postintervention interview to evaluate personal experiences, goal attainment, and future maintenance of acquired skills. Each class covered specific exercises and topics within the context of mindfulness training, i.e., practices during lying, sitting, and dynamic yoga postures, as well as during everyday life, e.g., stressful situations and social interactions. Mindfulness exercises included observation of sensory, affective, and cognitive domains of perceptible experience. The all-day retreat integrated familiar exercises and presented new ones."
   - "All patients in the usual care (UC) group (and in the MBI group) received regular, currently optimal medical care during the duration of the study, as provided by the neurology department of the hospital.    The trial examined the effects of a mindfulness-based intervention (MBI) compared to usual care (UC) upon HRQOL, depression, and fatigue among adults with relapsing-remitting or secondary progressive MS.

   The trial used intention-to-treat analysis and included all data in the analysis of the primary outcome.

llm_message:
1. Eligibility:
   - "Patients were recruited from Unità Organica di riabilitazione Intensiva Neuromotoria (UOrIN, Italy), Foundation Institute Guttmann (FPING, Spain) and from National Multiple Sclerosis centre (NMSc, Belgium). UOrIN included stroke patients, FPING tBI patients and NMSc MS patients."
   - "the subjects were eligible for recruiting if they met the following criteria: (1) age > 18 years; (2) established diagnosis of the specific pathological condition MS, stroke or tBI;"
   - "exclusions were: a) disturbed upper limb function not related to MS, tBI or stroke;"

2. The eligibility criteria for this trial are relatively pragmatic, as they include a wide range of patients with different neurological conditions. The inclusion criteria are broad and do not involve many exclusions. The exclusion criteria are related to medical conditions that would interfere with the intervention, which is a common and necessary approach in clinical trials. Score: [4]

3. Recruitment:
   - "the study design was partly a randomized multicenter clinical trial (rct) to compare the results of the control group which received usual care and general exercises to the intervention group which used the H-caD system at home for one month."
   - "the study also comprised a patient-control design for the intervention group to investigate if the H-caD system maintained the same functional ability in the group of patients who underwent the intervention of the H-caD system compared to usual care they received before and after the intervention."

llm_message:
1. Eligibility:
   - "Patients in South East London who were severely affected by MS were referred by clinicians to the trial."
   - "Inclusion criteria were patients in South East London, living with MS and deemed (by clinicians) to have one or more of unresolved symptoms, psychoso-social concerns, end-of-life issues, progressive illness, or complex needs (i.e., palliative care needs)."
   - "Exclusion criteria included if the referring staff or the screening deemed patients had very urgent needs or were deteriorating rapidly when imme-diate referral to the service was offered."

2. The eligibility criteria in this trial are relatively pragmatic, as they aim to include patients with palliative care needs who are severely affected by MS. The inclusion criteria are broad and based on clinical judgment, while the exclusion criteria are minimal. The trial does not seem to use any specific selection tests or strict exclusion criteria, which is consistent with a pragmatic approach. However, the fact that patients were referred by clinicians might introduce some selection bias, which could make the trial less pragmatic. Overall, the eligibility criteria seem to be relatively pragmatic, but not entirely free from explanatory elements.

   Score: [4]

3. Recruitment:
   - "After baseline interview, patients were randomly allocated to either a multiprofessional palliative care team (PCT) immediately (fast track) or the control care group who continued best usual care for three months and then were offered the PCT."
   - "Reasons for drop out, no interview, and refusal were recorded whenever possible."

4. The recruitment process in this trial is relatively pragmatic, as patients were randomly allocated to either the intervention or control group after a baseline interview. The fact that patients were not blinded to their group allocation might introduce some bias, but this is a common limitation in many trials. The reasons for dropout and refusal were recorded, which is a good practice that increases the transparency and generalizability of the trial. However, the fact that patients were recruited by clinicians might introduce some selection bias, which could make the trial less pragmatic. Overall, the recruitment process seems to be relatively pragmatic, but not entirely free from explanatory elements.

   Score: [4]

5. Setting:
   - "After consent and baseline interview, the researcher e-mailed relevant data to independent statisticians who conducted the randomization using the minimization method to give an equal balance of gender, age, date of diagnosis, and according to whether patients could or could not communicate."
   - "Patients were randomized to receive either the PCT immediately (fast track) or usual best practice alone (control) for 12 weeks, after which they were offered the service."

6. The setting of this trial is relatively pragmatic, as patients were randomized to receive either the intervention or control group in their usual care setting. The fact that the trial used a minimization method to balance the groups is a good practice that increases the internal validity of the trial. However, the fact that patients were not blinded to their group allocation might introduce some bias, which could make the trial less pragmatic. Overall, the setting seems to be relatively pragmatic, but not entirely free from explanatory elements.

   Score: [4]

7. Organization:
   - "In addition to continuing to receive usual services (see below), patients in the fast-track group received care from a PCT."
   - "For patients randomized to the control group, community and hospital services (including neurologists, MS nurses, re-habilitation, neurological, and social services) were offered as usual."

8. The organization of care delivery in this trial is relatively pragmatic, as patients in the intervention group received care from a PCT in addition to their usual services. The fact that the trial used a minimization method to balance the groups is a good practice that increases the internal validity of the trial. However, the fact that patients were not blinded to their group allocation might introduce some bias, which could make the trial less pragmatic. Overall, the organization of care delivery seems to be relatively pragmatic, but not entirely free from explanatory elements.

   Score: [4]

9. Flexibility (delivery):
   - "Patients had one to three contacts (visits and/or phone calls) from the PCT, although a small number (around 12%) were referred for longer-term ‘‘community’’ palliative care."
   - "For patients randomized to the control group, community and hospital services (including neurologists, MS nurses, re-habilitation, neurological, and social services) were offered as usual."

10. The flexibility in how the intervention is delivered in this trial is relatively pragmatic, as patients had one to three contacts with the PCT, although a small number were referred for longer-term care. The fact that the trial used a minimization method to balance the groups is a good practice that increases the internal validity of the trial. However, the fact that patients were not blinded to their group allocation might introduce some bias, which could make the trial less pragmatic. Overall, the flexibility in how the intervention is delivered seems to be relatively pragmatic, but not entirely free from explanatory elements.

    Score: [4]

11. Flexibility (adherence):
   - "In some trials eg surgical trials where patients are being operated on or Intensive Care Unit trials where patients are being given IV drug therapy, this domain is not applicable as there is no compliance issue after consent has been given, so this score should be left blank."

12. The flexibility in how participants must adhere to the intervention in this trial is not applicable, as there is no compliance issue after consent has been given. This is consistent with a pragmatic approach, as the trial does not impose any unnecessary restrictions on participants' adherence to the intervention.

    Score: [NA]

13. Follow-up:
   - "We conducted face-to-face interviews with patients and gave self-complete questionnaires to caregivers."
   - "We collected outcome and cost data at baseline (before randomization) and at 6, 12, 18 (only control groupdafter they received the PCT), and 24 weeks."

14. The intensity of measurement and follow-up of participants in this trial is relatively pragmatic, as the trial collected outcome and cost data at multiple time points, including before randomization and after the intervention. The fact that the trial used a minimization method to balance the groups is a good practice that increases the internal validity of the trial. However, the fact that patients were not blinded to their group allocation might introduce some bias, which could make the trial less pragmatic. Overall, the intensity of measurement and follow-up seems to be relatively pragmatic, but not entirely free from explanatory elements.

    Score: [4]

15. Primary outcome:
   - "Our standardized questionnaires included the Palliative Care Outcome Scale (POS-8), comprising eight questions on anxiety, patient and carer concerns, and practical needs, each rated 0e4; a single-item POS pain score (rated 0 [best] to 4 [worst]); and caregivers’ burden (using the 12-item version of the Zarit Carer Burden Inventory [ZBI])."
   - "Higher scores represent greater problems on all the scales."

16. The primary outcome in this trial is relatively pragmatic, as it includes measures of anxiety, patient and carer concerns, practical needs, and caregivers' burden. The fact that the trial used a minimization method to balance the groups is a good practice that increases the internal validity of the trial. However, the fact that patients were not blinded to their group allocation might introduce some bias, which could make the trial less pragmatic. Overall, the primary outcome seems to be relatively pragmatic, but not entirely free from explanatory elements.

    Score: [4]

17. Primary analysis:
   - "We planned an intention-to-treat analysis, irrespective of whether patients were assessed as having palliative care needs or the nature of contact with the PCT."
   - "We tested the differences between the two arms (expressed as differences between follow-up and baseline interviews) using one-way analysis of variance (ANOVA), checking statistical assumptions and adjusting for baseline scores."

18. The primary analysis in this trial is relatively pragmatic, as it used an intention-to-treat analysis and adjusted for baseline scores. The fact that the trial used a minimization method to balance the groups is a good practice that increases the internal validity of the trial. However, the fact that patients were not blinded to their group allocation might introduce some bias, which could make the trial less pragmatic. Overall, the primary analysis seems to be relatively pragmatic, but not entirely free from explanatory elements.

    Score: [4]

llm_message:
1. Eligibility:
   - "The study population was low-disability RRMS patients with or without support partner. Eligibility criteria for patients: diagnosis RRMS since at least one year, EDSS score ≤4.0, no symptoms suggestive of a relapse, no relapse in the preceding four weeks, willing and capable of participating in the investigations, and having access to the internet for performing the web-based assessments."
   - "Eligibility criteria for support partners: willing and capable of participating in the investigations, and having access to the internet."
   - "Interested patients were contacted by a registered nurse experienced in MS (MH) by phone to check diagnosis and eligibility criteria."
   - "The enrolment started February 2013 and ended April 2016."

2. The full text provides information about the eligibility criteria for both patients and support partners. The criteria are not very restrictive, and the enrolment period is quite long, indicating a more pragmatic approach. However, the fact that patients were contacted by a registered nurse experienced in MS to check diagnosis and eligibility criteria suggests a more explanatory approach. Overall, the eligibility domain seems to be somewhere in the middle of the pragmatic-explanatory continuum.

   Score: [3]

3. Recruitment:
   - "Patients were recruited from all over the Netherlands by the patient organisation NMSF, Rotterdam, the Netherlands."
   - "Interested patients were contacted by a registered nurse experienced in MS (MH) by phone to check diagnosis and eligibility criteria."
   - "The enrolment started February 2013 and ended April 2016."

4. The full text provides limited information about the recruitment process. It is not clear how patients were identified and approached by the patient organisation NMSF. The fact that interested patients were contacted by a registered nurse experienced in MS to check diagnosis and eligibility criteria suggests a more explanatory approach. However, the enrolment period is quite long, indicating a more pragmatic approach. Overall, the recruitment domain seems to be somewhere in the middle of the pragmatic-explanatory continuum.

   Score: [3]

5. Setting:
   - "CDT was given during three consecutive days in Zorghotel Spelderholt, Beekbergen, the Netherlands, a facility especially equipped for the accommodation of people with impaired health."
   - "The number of sessions, their schedule, and their duration are presented in the Appendix (see App 1)."

6. The full text provides clear information about the setting of the trial, which is a facility especially equipped for the accommodation of people with impaired health. The setting seems to be quite pragmatic, as it is designed to accommodate the needs of the patients.

   Score: [5]

7. Organisation:
   - "The multidisciplinary team included a psychiatrist, psychiatric nurse, neurologist, registered nurse specialized in MS, physiotherapist, dance therapist, and a person with MS."
   - "All professional team members were formally trained in their respective disciplines and all members were experienced in the field of MS."
   - "Before starting the first CDT of the observational study, team members held two plenary sessions, in which the psychiatrist and psychiatric nurse informed the other members about this social cognitive theory-based approach, and during which the team became familiar with the concept, and each team member’s specific contribution to CDT."
   - "The members respected and understood the participants’ individual qualities and differences, and they stimulated, defied and confronted them to explore and push their boundaries."
   - "During the consultations they had a professional and informative role. In the small group sessions every team member focused on its own area of interest."

7. The full text provides detailed information about the organisation of the trial, including the composition and training of the multidisciplinary team. The team members were experienced in the field of MS and had specific roles in the CDT. The organisation seems to be quite pragmatic, as it is designed to provide the best possible care for the patients.

   Score: [5]

8. Flexibility (delivery):
   - "CDT’s components are large group sessions, small group sessions, consultations (carrousel), a theatre evening, and start of the day with a joint activity (optional)."
   - "Large group sessions include plenary sessions–where participants make optimal use of their existing potentials, learn how to support and encourage other participants, and experiment how to give the required feedback to the multidisciplinary team–, and group sessions in which half of the participants take part–where they examine and identify which stressors have to be addressed most, and formulate one or two realizable individual aims."
   - "After having identified and formulated individual stressors and aims, participants sign in for one or more group consultations, during which they verify whether their aims are realiz

able by asking the members of the multidisciplinary team for aim-related medical information."
   - "Small group sessions form the actual training. Depending on their individual goals the participants sign up for the training groups ‘Body’, ‘Feeling’ or ‘Life’, to work out their aims and to experiment whether they can reduce their stressors."
   - "On the informal theatre evening the participants practice to change roles and to show their potentials by openly experimenting. They do their best to perform before each other and the team. The jointly created evening performance increases the cohesion within the group and teaches participants to find an equilibrium between consuming and action."
   - "During an optional joint activity (walk in the woods) at the start of the day the participants experiment with physical challenges and with the management of their energy."

8. The full text provides detailed information about the flexibility of the CDT delivery. The CDT includes various components, such as large group sessions, small group sessions, consultations, a theatre evening, and a joint activity. The participants can choose the training groups that best suit their individual goals. The flexibility of the CDT delivery seems to be quite pragmatic.

   Score: [5]

9. Flexibility (adherence):
   - "The MS diagnosis was not confirmed by a neurologist."
   - "The criterion of EDSS ≤4.0 was checked by assessing whether the patient was self-sufficient and able to walk ≤500 meters without aid or rest."
   - "In addition, to assess the degree of disability, the EDSS score was further quantified on-site by an experienced neurologist, prior to the start of CDT, in patients randomized to the intervention; and in those control patients who chose to receive CDT after study completion."

9. The full text provides limited information about the flexibility of the CDT adherence. The MS diagnosis was not confirmed by a neurologist, and the EDSS score was checked by assessing whether the patient was self-sufficient and able to walk ≤500 meters without aid or rest. However, the EDSS score was further quantified on-site by an experienced neurologist, prior to the start of CDT, in patients randomized to the intervention. The flexibility of the CDT adherence seems to be quite pragmatic, but the lack of information about the control group makes it difficult to assess this domain.

   Score: [NA]

1. Eligibility:
   - "The study population was low-disability RRMS patients with or without support partner. Eligibility criteria for patients: diagnosis RRMS since at least one year, EDSS score ≤4.0, no symptoms suggestive of a relapse, no relapse in the preceding four weeks, willing and capable of participating in the investigations, and having access to the internet for performing the web-based assessments."
   - "Eligibility criteria for support partners: willing and capable of participating in the investigations, and having access to the internet."
   - "Interested patients were contacted by a registered nurse experienced in MS (MH) by phone to check diagnosis and eligibility criteria."
   - "The enrolment started February 2013 and ended April 2016."

   - "The multidisciplinary team included a psychiatrist, psychiatric nurse, neurologist, registered nurse specialized in MS, physiotherapist, dance therapist, and a person with MS."
   - "All professional team members were formally trained in their respective disciplines and all members were experienced in the field of MS."
   - "Before starting the first CDT of the observational study, team members held two plenary sessions, in which the psychiatrist and psychiatric nurse informed the other members about this social cognitive theory-based approach, and during which the team became familiar with the concept, and each team member’s specific contribution to CDT."
   - "The members respected and understood the participants’ individual qualities and differences, and they stimulated, defied and confronted them to explore and push their boundaries."
   - "During the consultations they had a professional and informative role. In the small group sessions every team member focused on its own area of interest."

   - "CDT’s components are large group sessions, small group sessions, consultations (carrousel), a theatre evening, and start of the day with a joint activity (optional)."
   - "Large group sessions include plenary sessions–where participants make optimal use of their existing potentials, learn how to support and encourage other participants, and experiment how to give the required feedback to the multidisciplinary team–, and group sessions in which half of the participants take part–where they examine and identify which stressors have to be addressed most, and formulate one or two realizable individual aims."
   - "After having identified and formulated individual stressors and aims, participants sign in for one or more group consultations, during which they verify whether their aims are realiz

able by asking the members of the multidisciplinary team for aim-related medical information."
   - "Small group sessions form the actual training. Depending on their individual goals the participants sign up for the training groups ‘Body’, ‘Feeling’ or ‘Life’, to work out their aims and to experiment whether they can reduce their stressors."
   - "On the informal theatre evening the participants practice to change roles and to show their potentials by openly experimenting. They do their best to perform before each other and the team. The jointly created evening performance increases the cohesion within the group and teaches participants to find an equilibrium between consuming and action."
   - "During an optional joint activity (walk in the woods) at the start of the day the participants experiment with physical challenges and with the management of their energy."
